awd_abstract_narration:
The Educators' Equity in STEM II project tests and refines a model of professional development for secondary teachers and postsecondary faculty at community colleges whose responsibilities are in the area of career and technician education.  The project engages 100 participants (technician faculty and teachers) and 100 supporters (key personnel in selected departments and on campuses) in testing, refining and implementing equitable and inclusive students experiences in classrooms that transform teaching practices in courses in technician education programs.  The cornerstone of the proposed professional development is the "Micro-messaging to Reach and Teach Every Student Program" developed with funding from programs administered in the NSF Division of Human Resource Development and the Division of Undergraduate Education. Based on a localized implementation of the program (prior support), the project hypothesizes that attention and action focused on micro-messaging geared to increasing equity and inclusiveness in the classroom could increase the confidence and success of students in technician education programs across the nation.  

Project effectiveness will be assessed using the Learning Forward 2011 Standards for Professional Learning and a project evaluation that adapts and integrates the Context-Input-Process-Product Evaluation model with models for evaluating professional development.  In recognition of performance appraisals at the secondary and post-secondary education levels, participants will earn graduate education credits through Castleton University in Vermont.

inst.inst_name: National Alliance for Partnerships in Equity Education Foundatio
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: NATIONAL ALLIANCE FOR PARTNERSHIPS IN EQUITY EDUCATION FOUNDATION, INC.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: National Alliance for Partnerships in Equity Education Foundatio

por.por_cntn:
In September 2016, the National Alliance for Partnerships in Equity (NAPE) Education Foundation received a 3-year award ($899,961) from the National Science Foundation (NSF) Advanced Technological Education Program (ATE) to conduct the Educators Equity in STEM II project (EESTEM II, DUE 1601548). This grant builds on the foundation laid by a prior project, Educators Equity in STEM Academy (DUE 1104163, $1,059,944), which ended January 31, 2016. The project was awarded a third no-cost extension and ended on August 31, 2022. The NAPE Education Foundation works to build capacity to implement effective equity solutions in the workforce education system and is the fiscal agent for EESTEM II.

The EESTEM II project's goal was to develop an effective model for national delivery of a high-quality professional development (PD) program, with fidelity to community college and secondary career and technical educators to enhance their teaching skills and improve program and campus practices leading to increased educational outcomes for women and girls, students of color, and students from special populations including students with disabilities.

The Educators' Equity STEM Academy used NAPE's comprehensive educational equity curriculum, The Micromessaging to Reach and Teach Every Student, to enhance teaching skills and practices, and educator self-efficacy in creating equitable learning environments. NAPE worked with Dona Ana Community College, New Mexico and Stark State College, Ohio to create and deliver a rigorous PD program for educators. The PD included four components: (1) a 4-day Summer Institute, (2) eight structured and facilitated monthly Professional Learning Communities (PLCs), (3) tools and resources, and (4) a Capstone Presentation for educators to present their Action Research for Equity Projects. 

Intellectual Merit

The project enhanced the body of knowledge through:

(1) Publishing an extensive literature review on equitable access to STEM and CTE using an intersectional lens to examine how individual learners are affected by the dynamics within education, careers, and community. This work resulted in a new publication, Equity in CTE & STEM: Root Causes and Strategies, and an associated Call to Action and Summary Table that were piloted in PD engagements with 10 organizations around the country, posted on the NAPE website and shared widely with members and partners via NAPE's newsletter and at conferences and webinars.

(2) Completing an update of the Micromessaging to Reach and Teach Every Student curriculum reflecting several major shifts, including more robust and current research, incorporating the concepts of andragogy, emphasizing critical consciousness, adding historical context (e.g., race, ability, gender identity), and using terminology that is more current and inclusive.

(3) Launching and sustaining Affinity Groups to continue the inquiry into best practices for equitable classrooms resulting in innovations to the Micromessaging Academy materials that have been shared on NAPE's member podcast, "Reconnect, Reset, Restart."

(4) Publishing, or submitting for publication, two manuscripts about lessons learned and outcomes for the project. The first paper, titled "Changemakers for equity: CTE teachers examine unconscious bias through micromessaging," was published in the February 2022 edition of Techniques, a practitioner journal of the Association for Career and Technical Education, reaching an audience of 55,000 practitioners. The second paper, titled "Encouraging Educational Equity, One Workshop at a Time: An Analysis of NAPE?s Micromessaging Academy," was submitted for publication to the refereed journals Leadership and Research in Education and the Journal of Urban Learning, Teaching, and Research.

Broader Impacts

The EE-STEM II Project has helped educators increase their understanding of how microaggressions can create barriers to students' access and success in STEM and CTE pathways and they learn how to take action to interrupt and remove those barriers. Significant positive student outcomes for women and girls, students of color, and students with disabilities have been observed, and the project met or exceeded all of its goals. 

Participants reported critically examining the sources and impacts of micromessages gave them new awareness and skills. Most often, they said that they began to identify and challenge cultural stereotypes in their lives, on their campuses or institutions, and among their interactions with students. 

Most participants (93%) reported that, by the end of the Academy, they had shifted some of their pedagogy. Eighty-four percent had observed a positive impact on students: increased student engagement, increased self-efficacy and a greater sense of belonging. Participants also reported a greater institutional awareness of the need to create equitable learning environments for students and a feeling of empowerment to make changes in their classrooms and schools.

Notably, when Summer Institute participants were surveyed three to four years later, 100% of respondents reported that they had observed at least some impact on their students, with 50% reporting high impact. Outcomes from this project will help NAPE to continue to expand and improve its professional development offerings to increase student access, educational equity and workforce diversity in high-skill, high-wage, and high-demand STEM and technical education programs.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/08/2022
Modified by: Silvia C Ramos
